questions.body: It takes 4 seconds for light to travel between the Earth and the Moon.
All the planets turn in the same direction around the Sun.
At the equator, Earth rotates on its axis at a speed of 1,670 km/h (1,037 m.p.h.).
The coast of South America is moving closer to the coast of Africa.
The fly flaps its wings approximately 10 times per second.
Sound travels more quickly through water than through air.
A tropical storm becomes a hurricane when wind speed exceeds 119 km/h (74 m.p.h.).
Our eyes don’t perceive motion in a fluid way.
A hummingbird’s heart rate can reach 1,000 beats per minute.
A plane by the name of Solar Impulse flew around the world powered only by solar energy.
In tennis, no woman has ever served at over 200 km/h (124.27 m.p.h.).
When hunting prey, cheetahs can run at speeds of 100 km/h (62 m.p.h.).
In 1899, the electricity-powered La Jamais Contente (“The Never Satisfied”) became the first motor vehicle to hit the 100 km/h (62 m.p.h.) mark.
On Neptune, winds can blow at almost twice the speed of sound.
On the Moon, objects fall 6 times more slowly than on Earth.
If you were to look down from the North Pole, you would see the Earth turning clockwise on its axis.
The Moon’s influence on the tides is about 10 times that of the Sun’s influence on the tides.
In cinema, creating the effect of high speed requires projecting a higher-than-normal number of frames per second.
All our muscles have the same structure; only their functions vary.
The Moon is slowly moving towards the Earth.
Earth’s rotation is accelerating.
In one day, blood travels a total of 19,000 km (11,800 mi.).
When he broke the world record, Usain Bolt averaged a speed of 37.58 km/h (23.35 m.p.h.).
Motor neurons relay information at a speed of over 300 km/h (185 m.p.h.).
Each year, the Arctic tern travels a distance equivalent to the circumference of the Earth.
The largest known tree has a circumference of 137.8 ft. (42 m).
There are about as many trees as there are humans on Earth.
In the Amazon rainforest, trees capture about 95% of the light.
Forests cover about 70% of Earth’s land.
Alessandro Volta invented the electric battery in the late 1700s.
